content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would choose a strategy based on the potential earnings and the likelihood of my opponent choosing either R or B. Since the game has 75 rounds, it allows us to explore multiple scenarios.

Considering the payoff matrix, it is clear that both choices have their advantages. However, picking R results in earning 45$ when the opponent also chooses R but only 0$ when they choose B. On the other hand, choosing B earns me 42$ when the opponent picks R and 12$ when they also pick B.

To maximize my earnings, I should aim for as many opportunities to get the highest payout of 45$. However, it is challenging to predict the opponent's moves. Since both choices have their advantages, I might assume that the opponent is likely considering a similar strategy.

In this case, I could try to "punish" my opponent for choosing R when I choose B by taking the 42$ payout instead of 0$. This way, they may switch their strategy and choose B more often when I play R. On the other hand, if I pick R, I am giving them the opportunity to earn 45$, so they might be more inclined to choose R as well.

In conclusion, a rational choice would be to mix up my choices between R and B, aiming to maximize payouts while considering that the opponent might do the same. Therefore, my choice will be {R} or {B} based on the round number and my observations of the opponent's behavior. However, since I am an anonymous player, it is hard to predict the opponent's strategy accurately.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent also picked B in the previous round and we both received a payout of 12$, I would like to try switching my strategy in the next round. I will pick R for the next round, aiming to see if my opponent switches their choice as well or continues with the same strategy.

In this case, {R} is my choice for the next round. If my opponent also picks R, we both earn 45$. If they choose B, I will get 0$, and they will receive 42$. However, switching strategies might cause them to reconsider their choices as well, potentially leading to more varied outcomes in future rounds.

{R} is my choice for the next round, hoping that my opponent might start considering a different strategy. If they also pick R, we both earn 45$, but if they choose B again, I will receive 0$ once more, while they get 42$. However, sticking with my initial choice of R for multiple rounds could potentially lead to more chances of my opponent switching their strategy in the future and earning less themselves.
